block.p: A Union of Concerned Scientists study released last week found that establishing a national standard of 20 percent of American electricity coming from non-hydropower renewable energy by 2020, if combined with energy efficiency programs, would save consumers at least $70 billion, stimulate the economy, reduce the vulnerability of our energy infrastructure to terrorist attack, and greatly reduce air pollution and greenhouse gas emissions. A bill to achieve this has been introduced by Senator James M. Jeffords, and should be adopted as part of the Senate's overall energy package.

A Union of Concerned Scientists study released last week found that establishing a national standard of 20 percent of American electricity coming from non-hydropower renewable energy by 2020, if combined with energy efficiency programs, would save consumers at least $70 billion, stimulate the economy, reduce the vulnerability of our energy infrastructure to terrorist attack, and greatly reduce air pollution and greenhouse gas emissions. A bill to achieve this has been introduced by Senator James M. Jeffords, and should be adopted as part of the Senate's overall energy package.
Developing wind, solar, biomass, geothermal and other home-grown energy sources, along with increasing energy efficiency, is the best way to diversify America's energy supply.
ALAN NOGEE Director, Clean Energy Program Union of Concerned Scientists Boston, Oct. 25, 2001
